RAVINDRA 369 court of its pre-amendment power to award interest on pre-suit interest adjudged as such and not of the power to award future interest on the principal sum adjudged The present cases came up before the Constitution Bench on reference from a three-Judge Bench [(1996) 5 sec 279]. The common question of law arising in all these cases related to the meaning of the phrases "the principal sum adjudged" and "such principal sum", occurring in Section 34 of CPC, 1908 as amended by Act 66 of 1956. The appellant Bank sanctioned a loan to the respondent, who executed a demand promissory note for Rs 1,37,720. The loan carried interest at the rate of 11 % per annum with quarterly rests. Later, the appellant filed a suit for recovery of the total outstanding amount of Rs 1,51,825 including the interest charged. The High Court while upholding the trial court's decree for Rs 1,51,825 allowed pendente lite and future interest @ 11 % only on Rs 99,000 which was stated to be the principal sum. The appellant Bank was aggrieved by the High Court's decree to the extent future interest was not allowed on the entire amount of Rs 1,51,825. The Solicitor-General contended that the contract between the parties or an established bank practice (in the case of banking transactions) may provide for compounding of the interest on periodical rests and capitalising thereof with the principal, in which event, the amount debited in the account of the borrower shall shed its character as interest and become the principal and therefore shall have to be adjudged as "the principal sum" on the date of the suit. He added that once that was done, "the principal sum adjudged" shall be "such principal sum" for the purpose of interest pendente lite as also future interest. On the other hand, the debtors submitted that the acceptance of such a contention would defeat the legislative intent behind the amendment as it would mean the court awarding interest on interest. They added that notwithstanding the capitalisation of the interest, once the suit is filed and the matter enters the domain of the court under Section 34 CPC, nothing prevents the court from unscrambling the amalgam so as to sieve out the principal from interest and confine the award of interest pendente lite and post- decree to principal sum only. Deciding the question of law and leaving the individual cases to be decided by the appropriate Bench, the Constitution Bench Held: English decisions and decisions of the Supreme Court and almost all the High Courts have noticed and approved the long-established banking practice of charging interest at reasonable rates on periodical rests and capitalising the same on remaining unpaid. Such a practice is prevalent and also recognised in non- banking moneylending transactions. The legislature has stepped in from time to time to relieve the debtors from hardship whenever it has found this practice to be oppressive and needing to be curbed. The practice is permissible, legal and has been judicially upheld except when superseded by legislation. There is nothing wrong in the parties voluntarily entering into transactions, evidenced by deeds incorporating covenant or stipulation for payment of compound interest at reasonable rates, and authorising the creditor to capitalise the interest on the amount remaining unpaid so as to enable interest being charged at the agreed rate on the interest component of the capitalised sum for the succeeding period. Interest once capitalised, sheds its colour of being interest and becomes a part of principal so as to bind the debtor/borrower. (Paras 36 and 44) Reddie v. Penal interest can be charged only once for one period of default and therefore cannot be permitted to be capitalised. [Paras 38 and 55(1)] While decreeing a suit if the decree be for payment of money, the court would adjudge the principal sum on the date of the suit. The principal sum adjudged would be the sum actually loaned plus the amount of interest on periodical rests which according to the contract between the parties or the established banking practice has stood capitalised. Interest pendente lite and future interest (i.e. interest post- decree not exceeding 6 per cent per annum) shall be awarded on such principal sum i.e. the principal sum adjudged on the date of the suit. The underlying principle is that when b interest is debited to the account of the borrower on periodical rests, it is debited because of it having fallen due on that day. If the interest is not paid on the date due, from that date the creditor is deprived of such use of the money which it would have made if the debtor had paid the amount of interest on the date due. The creditor needs to be compensated for deprivation. Firstly, it prevents award of interest on the amount of interest so adjudged on the date of suit. Secondly, it brings the last clause of Section 34, by narrowing down its ambit, in conformity with the scope of the first clause insofar as the expression "the principal sum adjudged" occurring in the first part of Section 34 is concerned which has been e left untouched by amendment. The meaning to be assigned to this expression in the first part remains the same as it was even before the amendment. However, in the third part of Section 34 the words used were "on the aggregate sum so adjudged". The judicial opinion prevalent then was that "aggregate sum" contemplated the aggregate of (i) the principal sum adjudged, (ii) the interest from the date of the suit to the date of decree, and (iii) the pre-suit interest.
